awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Semiconductor Heterostructure Platform for Active Nonlocal Plasmonic and Hyperbolic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Multilayered composites, designed to combine the properties of reflective metals and transparent dielectrics, have the potential to revolutionize optical microscopy, control emission of molecules, and even to enable cloaks of invisibility. However, until now the advantages achieved with multilayered structures have been limited. Decreasing layer thickness, reducing absorption, and implementing optical gain have been named as some of the possible ways to advance the optics of multilayered media towards its revolutionary potential. In this project, our collaborative team will aim to understand, through carefully designed experimental, computational, and analytical studies, the optical response of free-electron plasma that underlines the photonics of multilayered composites. Of particular interest will be the limits of small layer thickness where quantum-mechanical effects are expected to manifest themselves, and the interaction between optical gain and loss. The program will present new opportunities for engaging students in interdisciplinary research and thus improve competitiveness of the US high-tech workforce. The team members will also implement a number of outreach events to broaden participation of school-aged and undergraduate students in STEM. 

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Plasmonic metamaterials -- nanostructured composites with tailored optical response resulting from metallic or highly doped semiconducting components -- promise to revolutionize our understanding of light-matter interactions, enabling new applications that include perfect light absorbers, invisibility cloaks, sub-wavelength imaging, focusing, and guiding. In this project the team will perform a comprehensive interdisciplinary study of semiconductor layered metamaterials, with a vision towards understanding the fundamentals of light-matter interaction in heterogeneous mesoscale plasmonic systems. Of particular interest will be (i) understanding the optical response of plasmonic systems where the motion of the free charges is confined by the geometry, leading to nonlocal electromagnetism and to (ii) fundamentals of light propagation, emission, and absorption in coupled nonlocal nanoplasmonic systems. The developed description of active nonlocal plasmonics will be applicable to multiple material platforms operating throughout optical spectrum. The proposed program will provide multiple opportunities for educating the next-generation interdisciplinary workforce and will serve as a platform for outreach activities targeting undergraduates, school students, and school teachers.

por.por_cntn:
During this project, our collaborative team aimed to understand, through carefully designed experimental, computational, and analytical studies, the optical response of free-electron plasma that underlines the photonics of multilayered composites. The goals of this program were to (i) understand the transition between the quantized and classical response of multilayer arrays as their thickness is reduced to ~5nm range (typical for quantum cascade structures) and (ii) understand the interplay between plasmonic loss and optical gain in the active plasmonic structures, with the ultimate goal of understanding and approaching the limits of light molding with composites. Importantly, since the mid-IR response of doped semiconductor multilayers is driven by free electrons, similar to the visible-frequency response of noble metals, the theoretical formalisms developed in this program were expected to be directly applicable to future studies of other plasmonic platforms, starting from noble metals at visible frequencies, to transparent oxides at near IR, to doped 2D materials at far-IR and THz frequencies.

All theoretical and experimental studies performed during the research program were focused on the case of uniaxial anisotropy. The general case of fully anisotropic dielectric permittivity tensor with the different values of all three primary components may lead to not only a quantitative change but also new physical phenomena. The team demonstrated that such fully-anisotropic (biaxial) metamaterials support novel “ghost” waves that combine the properties of both the evanescent and propagating modes, showing oscillatory decay even in the lossless limit. This behavior can lead to exact frequency degeneracies in guided modes.

Another area of focus during the team’s research was the diffraction limit. The diffraction limit is a fundamental law of nature that prevents information flow between subwavelength and macroscale areas. This The team was able to demonstrate a potential solution to this fundamental problem at mid-IR frequencies. The structures, termed photonic funnels, are conical systems with metallic walls isolating their cores from the environment, and the cores fabricated from the material platform developed in this program. We experimentally demonstrated individual funnels and arrays of funnels with output diameters as small as 1/35 of the free-space wavelength, as well as transmission of light through these structures. Our numerical analysis proves that the funnels provide a flexible platform for linking the diffraction-limited world with subwavelength areas. In particular, we demonstrated high-efficiency confinement of propagating light and high-efficiency outcoupling of light from nm-scale areas.

Also, through continued collaboration, the group was able to further move plasmonic-enhanced emission towards practical applications by demonstrating electrically pumped LED whose emission properties exceed those of state of the art – and thus highly optimized – devices.

In addition to the team’s research efforts, there were also efforts made to bring this knowledge to the broader research community. Unfortunately, the COVID pandemic strongly affected the team’s ability to participate in in-person outreach events. However, the team continued our educational mission and participated in several virtual outreach events. The team was able to organize and run a Fall 2019 outreach event with Austin Urban Scholars, where we worked with middle school students on a hands-on nanotechnology activity. There were also efforts made to present this material at conferences and workshops such as the Second Annual Vibrational Spectroscopy Workshop.
